raw_text:
White admits to Balco drugs link
 
 Banned American sprinter Kelli White says she knowingly took steroids given to her by Bay Area Lab Co-Operative (Balco) president Victor Conte.
 
 Conte faces a federal trial next year on charges of distributing steroids and tax evasion, and White said at first he tried to cover up what he was doing. "He's the one who told me that it wasn't what he said it was," White said in the San Francisco Chronicle. But she added: "It was my decision to go to him, not anybody else's." White said Conte at first told her the substance was flaxseed oil, only to change his story later. White failed a drugs test after winning the 100m and 200m titles at the 2003 world athletics championships. She was subsequently handed a two-year ban in May this year and has admitted taking the stimulant modafinil. At first, White claimed she took the drug to combat narcolepsy but she now takes full responsibility for her actions.
 
 "My whole belief about Victor is that he was selling a product," White said in the LA Times. "Whether it be a good product or a bad product, he was selling a product." White was introduced to Conte through her coach Remy Korchemy, who is also a defendant in the Balco case. The 27-year-old believes doping is so common in sport she felt compelled to cheat herself if she was to have any chance of winning. "I have no clue what it's going to take to change that," said White. "I would say I made a mistake and I would never, ever go back. "I would never recommend anyone to take that route."
llama3.2:1b: Kelli White, an American sprinter who won titles in 2003 and was banned for two years after failing a test, has admitted to taking steroids given to her by Balco president Victor Conte.
She initially claimed the substance was flaxseed oil but later changed her story, saying she now takes full responsibility for her actions.

White had claimed she took the stimulant modafinil for narcolepsy but now takes full responsibility for her actions.

While initially claiming modafinil use for narcolepsy, she now accepts full responsibility for doping and acknowledges that cheating was commonplace within sport.

At first, White said she took modafinil after winning the 100m and 200m titles at the 2003 World Athletics Championships.
She was later banned from sport for two years after a drugs test.
White believes Conte is selling anabolic steroids in sport.

Controversially, White also took modafinil for narcolepsy symptoms and has faced a two-year ban.
Introduced to Conte via coach Remy Korchemy, White believes doping is prevalent in sports and feels she had no choice but to cheat if she wanted success.
She now states her mistake and pledges never to recommend such actions again.

tinydolphin:1.1b: In a recent statement in the San Francisco Chronicle, American sprinter Kelli White claims she initially believed that Victor Conte of Bay Area Lab Co-Operative (Balco) was selling a good product.
However, as the truth about her doping habits became known, she began to understand that the situation was far from acceptable and had become an unwitting part of the world of sports doping.
White, initially banned for two years after failing a drugs test at the 2003 World Athletics Championships, has now admitted her involvement with Balco, which is co-owned by Victor Conte.
Conte was later charged by the federal government on charges of distributing steroids and tax evasion.
In response to White's confession, she stated that at first, she had believed Modafinil was a natural supplement used by her coach Remy Korchemy.

However, as further investigation revealed that it in fact contained the stimulant modafinil, she began to take full responsibility for her actions and now admits that she took the substance to boost her performance during the 2003 World Athletics Championships.
White's story serves as a stark reminder of the prevalence of doping in sports and highlights the lengths athletes are willing to go to maintain their competitive edge.

Despite her initial belief that Balco was offering a good product, she now understands that this was far from the truth and has made a commitment to cheat herself if she were to have any chance of winning.
Balco's founder Victor Conte has also been charged by the federal government with distributing steroids and tax evasion.

White's decision to confess highlights the importance of holding sports organizations accountable for their role in promoting performance-enhancing substances, as it serves as a wake-up call for athletes and fans alike to remember that doping can have serious consequences.
